verses.text: The beginning of the good news of Jesus, the Anointed One.
As it has been written in Isaiah the prophet: "Look—I am sending my messenger ahead of you, who will prepare your way;
a voice crying out in the wilderness: 'Prepare the way of the Lord, make his paths straight.'"
John appeared—the one baptizing in the wilderness—proclaiming a baptism of turning back for the release of sins.
And the whole Judean countryside was going out to him, and all the people of Jerusalem, and they were being baptized by him in the Jordan River, confessing their sins.
Now John was clothed in camel's hair with a leather belt around his waist, and he ate locusts and wild honey.
And he was proclaiming, saying: "One stronger than I is coming after me, whose sandal strap I am not worthy to stoop down and untie.
I baptized you with water, but he will baptize you with a holy spirit."
And it happened in those days that Jesus came from Nazareth of Galilee and was baptized in the Jordan by John.
And immediately, as he was coming up out of the water, he saw the heavens being torn open and the Spirit descending into him like a dove.
And a voice came from the heavens: "You are my Son, the Beloved—in you I delight."
And immediately the Spirit drives him out into the wilderness.
And he was in the wilderness forty days, being tested by the Adversary, and he was among the wild animals, and the angels were serving him.
And after John was handed over, Jesus came into Galilee proclaiming the good news of God
and saying: "The appointed time has been fulfilled and the kingdom of God has drawn near. Turn back and put your trust in the good news."
And passing along by the Sea of Galilee, he saw Simon and Andrew, Simon's brother, casting a net into the sea—for they were fishermen.
And Jesus said to them: "Come, follow me, and I will make you become fishers of people."
And immediately they left their nets and followed him.
And going on a little farther, he saw James the son of Zebedee and John his brother, and they were in the boat mending their nets.
And immediately he called them. And they left their father Zebedee in the boat with the hired workers and went off after him.
And they go into Capernaum. And immediately, on the Sabbath, he was teaching in the synagogue.
And they were astonished at his teaching, for he was teaching them as one having authority, and not as the scribes.
And immediately there was in their synagogue a man with an unclean spirit, and he cried out,
saying: "What do you want with us, Jesus of Nazareth? Have you come to destroy us? I know who you are—the Holy One of God!"
And Jesus rebuked him, saying: "Be silent and come out of him!"
And the unclean spirit, after convulsing him and crying out with a loud voice, came out of him.
And all were amazed, so that they kept debating among themselves, saying: "What is this? A new teaching! With authority he even commands the unclean spirits, and they obey him!"
And the news about him went out immediately everywhere into all the surrounding region of Galilee.
And immediately, after leaving the synagogue, they came into the house of Simon and Andrew, with James and John.
Now Simon's mother-in-law was lying sick with a fever, and immediately they tell him about her.
And coming to her, he raised her up, taking hold of her hand. And the fever left her, and she began serving them.
When evening came, after the sun had set, they were bringing to him all who were ill and those who were possessed by demons.
And the whole city had gathered at the door.
And he healed many who were ill with various diseases, and he cast out many demons. And he would not permit the demons to speak, because they knew him.
And very early in the morning, while it was still dark, he rose and went out and went away to a deserted place, and there he was praying.
And Simon and those with him hunted him down,
and they found him and say to him: "Everyone is looking for you."
And he says to them: "Let us go elsewhere, to the neighboring towns, so that I may proclaim there also—for this is why I came out."
And he went throughout all Galilee, proclaiming in their synagogues and casting out demons.
And a leper comes to him, pleading with him and kneeling, saying to him: "If you are willing, you are able to cleanse me."
And becoming angry, he stretched out his hand and touched him and says to him: "I am willing—be cleansed!"
And immediately the leprosy left him, and he was cleansed.
And sternly warning him, he immediately drove him out,
and says to him: "See that you say nothing to anyone, but go, show yourself to the priest and offer for your cleansing what Moses commanded, as a testimony to them."

But he went out and began to proclaim freely and spread the word, so that Jesus was no longer able to enter a city openly, but stayed outside in deserted places. And they kept coming to him from everywhere.

chapters.notes:
**"The Anointed One" (v. 1)**: Greek χριστός translates Hebrew *mashiach* ("messiah"). While "Christ" has become virtually a second name in English, the first-century reader would hear this as a title with royal and priestly connotations—"the anointed one" preserves this.

**"Turning back" (v. 4, 15)**: Greek μετάνοια is often rendered "repentance," but the modern English word emphasizes feeling sorry. The Greek (and underlying Hebrew *teshuvah*) emphasizes a complete reorientation—turning around and going a different direction.

**"Release of sins" (v. 4)**: Greek ἄφεσις means release, letting go, liberation. "Forgiveness" works but loses the sense of bondage being broken that ἄφεσις carries.

**"Being torn open" (v. 10)**: Greek σχίζω means to tear or rip violently—the same word used when the temple veil is "torn" at Jesus's death (15:38). Mark uses this forceful language rather than the gentler "opened" found in Matthew and Luke.

**"The Spirit descending into him" (v. 10)**: Greek εἰς αὐτόν is "into him," not merely "upon him" (ἐπί). Mark's language suggests penetration, not just alighting.

**"The Spirit drives him out" (v. 12)**: Greek ἐκβάλλει is the same forceful verb used for casting out demons. Most translations soften this to "sent" or "led," but Mark's language is deliberately violent.

**"The Adversary" (v. 13)**: Greek Σατανᾶς transliterates Hebrew *satan*, meaning "adversary" or "accuser." Preserving this meaning reminds readers this is a title/function, not merely a proper name.

**"The appointed time" (v. 15)**: Greek καιρός refers to a decisive or opportune moment, not mere chronological time (χρόνος). It's the pregnant moment when everything changes.

**Historic presents (v. 21, 37, 38, 40, 41, 44)**: Mark frequently shifts to present tense for vividness. I've preserved several instances where the Greek uses present tense ("they go," "say," "comes") to maintain Mark's urgent, immediate narrative style.

**"What do you want with us?" (v. 24)**: Greek τί ἡμῖν καὶ σοί is a Semitic idiom (lit. "what to us and to you?") expressing rejection or a desire for separation—"Leave us alone!" or "What business do you have with us?"

**"Becoming angry" (v. 41)**: The SBLGNT follows manuscripts reading ὀργισθείς ("becoming angry") rather than the more common σπλαγχνισθείς ("having compassion"). The harder reading is likely original—scribes would more readily change "angry" to "compassionate" than vice versa. Jesus's anger may be directed at the disease, the purity system that marginalized lepers, or the suffering itself.

**"Hunted him down" (v. 36)**: Greek καταδιώκω is a strong verb suggesting pursuit—more intense than simply "looking for."

**"Drove him out" (v. 43)**: Again ἐκβάλλω—Jesus "casts out" the healed man with the same verb used for exorcism. Combined with the stern warning (ἐμβριμάομαι, a word suggesting snorting or deep agitation), Mark portrays Jesus with striking emotional intensity.

verses.text: And when he entered Capernaum again after some days, it was heard that he was at home.
And so many gathered that there was no longer room for them, not even around the door, and he was speaking the word to them.
And they come bringing to him a paralyzed man, carried by four men.
And being unable to bring him near because of the crowd, they removed the roof above where Jesus was, and after digging through it, they lower the mat on which the paralyzed man was lying.
And seeing their faith, Jesus says to the paralyzed man, "Child, your sins are forgiven."
Now some of the scribes were sitting there, reasoning in their hearts:
"Why does this man speak like this? He blasphemes! Who can forgive sins except God alone?"
And immediately perceiving in his spirit that they were reasoning this way within themselves, Jesus says to them, "Why are you reasoning these things in your hearts?
Which is easier—to say to the paralyzed man, 'Your sins are forgiven,' or to say, 'Rise, pick up your mat, and walk'?
But so that you may know that the Son of Man has authority on earth to forgive sins"—he says to the paralyzed man—
"I say to you, rise, pick up your mat, and go to your home."
And he rose and immediately picked up his mat and went out before them all, so that they were all astounded and glorified God, saying, "We have never seen anything like this!"
And he went out again beside the sea, and the whole crowd kept coming to him, and he was teaching them.
And passing by, he saw Levi the son of Alphaeus sitting at the toll booth, and he says to him, "Follow me." And he rose and followed him.
And it happens that he was reclining at table in his house, and many tax collectors and sinners were reclining together with Jesus and his disciples, for there were many who were following him.
And the scribes of the Pharisees, seeing that he was eating with sinners and tax collectors, were saying to his disciples, "Why does he eat with tax collectors and sinners?"
And when Jesus heard this, he says to them, "Those who are strong have no need of a physician, but those who are sick. I did not come to call the righteous, but sinners."
Now John's disciples and the Pharisees were fasting. And they come and say to him, "Why do John's disciples and the disciples of the Pharisees fast, but your disciples do not fast?"
And Jesus said to them, "The wedding guests cannot fast while the bridegroom is with them, can they? As long as they have the bridegroom with them, they cannot fast.
But days will come when the bridegroom is taken away from them, and then they will fast on that day."
"No one sews a patch of unshrunk cloth onto an old garment. Otherwise, the new piece pulls away from the old, and a worse tear results.
And no one puts fresh wine into old wineskins. Otherwise, the wine will burst the skins, and both the wine and the skins are destroyed. Rather, fresh wine goes into new wineskins."
And it happened that he was passing through the grain fields on the Sabbath, and his disciples began to make their way, plucking the heads of grain.
And the Pharisees were saying to him, "Look—why are they doing what is not permitted on the Sabbath?"
And he says to them, "Have you never read what David did when he was in need and hungry, he and those with him—

how he entered the house of God in the time of Abiathar the high priest, and ate the bread of the Presence, which no one is permitted to eat except the priests, and gave it also to those who were with him?"
And he was saying to them, "The Sabbath was made for humanity, not humanity for the Sabbath.
Therefore the Son of Man is lord even of the Sabbath."

chapters.notes:
**Historic present tense**: Mark frequently uses the present tense for past events (ἔρχονται "they come," λέγει "he says," χαλῶσι "they lower"). This creates vividness and immediacy. I have preserved this feature rather than smoothing it into past tense, as it reflects Mark's distinctive narrative style.

**"At home" (v. 1)**: ἐν οἴκῳ can mean "in a house" or "at home." Given that Capernaum served as Jesus's base of operations, "at home" captures the sense that he had returned to a familiar place.

**"Removed the roof... after digging through" (v. 4)**: The Greek uses cognate emphasis (ἀπεστέγασαν τὴν στέγην, "unroofed the roof") and then ἐξορύξαντες ("having dug out"). Palestinian roofs were typically made of wooden beams covered with branches and packed mud/clay, which could literally be dug through. This detail reflects the original setting.

**"Mat" (vv. 4, 9, 11, 12)**: κράβαττος refers to a poor person's pallet or sleeping mat—a humble piece of bedding, not a proper bed frame. "Mat" better captures this than the more formal "bed."

**"God alone" (v. 7)**: εἷς ὁ θεός echoes the Shema of Deuteronomy 6:4, which declares the oneness of God. The scribes' theological objection is rooted in Jewish monotheism.

**"The Son of Man" (vv. 10, 28)**: This phrase (ὁ υἱὸς τοῦ ἀνθρώπου) renders Aramaic בר נש (bar enash). It functions both as an idiom for "a human being" and as an allusion to Daniel 7:13-14, where "one like a son of man" receives authority from God. The original audience would have heard both resonances.

**"Reclining at table" (v. 15)**: κατακεῖσθαι and συνανέκειντο refer to the practice of reclining on couches during formal meals. Table fellowship was deeply significant—eating with someone implied acceptance and social solidarity. This is why the Pharisees' objection has such force.

**"Wedding guests" (v. 19)**: οἱ υἱοὶ τοῦ νυμφῶνος literally means "sons of the bridal chamber"—a Semitic idiom for those who participate in the wedding celebration, the bridegroom's companions.

**"Taken away" (v. 20)**: ἀπαρθῇ suggests forcible removal, foreshadowing Jesus's violent death. This is the earliest hint of the passion in Mark's Gospel.

**"Fresh wine... new wineskins" (v. 22)**: Greek distinguishes νέον (new in time, freshly made) from καινούς (new in quality, unused). Fresh wine still fermenting would burst old, inflexible wineskins.

**"Humanity" (vv. 27-28)**: ἄνθρωπος here is generic—referring to human beings as such, not specifically males. "Humanity" captures this better than "man" in contemporary English.

verses.text: And he entered a synagogue again, and there was a man there who had a withered hand.
They were watching him closely to see whether he would heal him on the Sabbath, so that they might bring charges against him.
And he says to the man with the withered hand, "Stand up and come to the center."
And he says to them, "Is it permitted on the Sabbath to do good or to do evil, to save a life or to kill?" But they kept silent.
And looking around at them with anger, grieved at the hardness of their hearts, he says to the man, "Stretch out your hand." And he stretched it out, and his hand was restored.
Going out, the Pharisees immediately began plotting with the Herodians against him, how they might destroy him.
Jesus withdrew with his disciples to the sea, and a great crowd from Galilee followed. And from Judea
and from Jerusalem and from Idumea and from beyond the Jordan and from around Tyre and Sidon—a great crowd, hearing all he was doing, came to him.
And he told his disciples to have a small boat ready for him because of the crowd, so they would not crush him.
For he had healed many, so that all who had afflictions were pressing upon him to touch him.
And whenever the unclean spirits saw him, they would fall down before him and cry out, "You are the Son of God!"
And he sternly warned them many times not to make him known.
And he goes up the mountain and summons those he himself wanted, and they came to him.
And he appointed twelve, so that they might be with him and so that he might send them out to proclaim
and to have authority to cast out demons.
He appointed the Twelve: to Simon he gave the name Peter;
and James the son of Zebedee and John the brother of James—to them he gave the name Boanerges, which means Sons of Thunder;
and Andrew and Philip and Bartholomew and Matthew and Thomas and James the son of Alphaeus and Thaddaeus and Simon the Zealot
and Judas Iscariot, who also handed him over.
And he comes home, and the crowd gathers again, so that they were not even able to eat a meal.
When his family heard this, they went out to seize him, for they were saying, "He has lost his mind."
And the scribes who had come down from Jerusalem were saying, "He has Beelzebul," and "By the ruler of the demons he casts out demons."
And summoning them, he spoke to them in comparisons: "How can Satan cast out Satan?
If a kingdom is divided against itself, that kingdom cannot stand.
And if a household is divided against itself, that household will not be able to stand.
And if Satan has risen up against himself and is divided, he cannot stand—his end has come.
But no one can enter the strong man's house and plunder his possessions unless he first binds the strong man; then he can plunder his house.
"Truly I tell you, all sins will be forgiven the sons of men, and whatever blasphemies they utter.
But whoever blasphemes against the Holy Spirit never has forgiveness, but is guilty of an eternal sin"—
because they were saying, "He has an unclean spirit."
And his mother and his brothers come, and standing outside they sent word to him, calling for him.
A crowd was sitting around him, and they say to him, "Look, your mother and your brothers are outside asking for you."
And answering them he says, "Who is my mother and who are my brothers?"
And looking around at those seated in a circle around him, he says, "Look—my mother and my brothers!
For whoever does the will of God, this one is my brother and sister and mother."

chapters.notes:
**"Withered" (v. 1, 3)**: The Greek ἐξηραμμένην (perfect passive of ξηραίνω) means "dried up" or "withered"—the hand had atrophied and become useless.

**"Hardness of their hearts" (v. 5)**: πώρωσις originally referred to the calcified growth that forms around a broken bone, creating hardened, insensitive tissue. The image is of hearts that have become calloused and unresponsive.

**"Afflictions" (v. 10)**: μάστιγας literally means "whips" or "scourges," used metaphorically for diseases or sufferings—illnesses experienced as divine lashings.

**"Simon the Zealot" (v. 18)**: Καναναῖον is not "Canaanite" but derives from Aramaic קנאן (qan'an), meaning "zealous one." Luke's parallel uses the Greek equivalent Ζηλωτής. This may indicate membership in the Zealot movement or simply fervent religious zeal.

**"His family" (v. 21)**: οἱ παρ' αὐτοῦ literally "those from beside him"—an idiom for one's relatives or associates. The context (connecting to v. 31) confirms these are his family members.

**"He has lost his mind" (v. 21)**: ἐξέστη means "he is beside himself" or "out of his mind"—his family thought he had become unhinged.

**"Comparisons" (v. 23)**: παραβολαῖς—while traditionally "parables," here Jesus is using analogies and comparisons to make his argument, not telling narrative parables.

**"Sons of men" (v. 28)**: τοῖς υἱοῖς τῶν ἀνθρώπων is a Semitic idiom meaning "human beings." Retaining "sons of men" preserves the Hebrew Bible resonance (cf. Psalm 8:4).

**"Handed him over" (v. 19)**: παρέδωκεν can mean "betrayed," but its primary sense is "handed over, delivered up." This translation preserves the ambiguity present in the Greek while also connecting to the theological theme of Jesus being "handed over" that runs through the passion narrative.

verses.text: And again he began to teach beside the sea. And such a vast crowd gathered around him that he got into a boat and sat on the water, while the whole crowd faced the sea, standing on the shore.
And he was teaching them many things in parables, and he said to them in his teaching:
"Listen! Look—the sower went out to sow.
And it happened that as he sowed, some seed fell along the path, and the birds came and devoured it.
And other seed fell on rocky ground where it did not have much soil, and immediately it sprang up because it had no depth of soil.
But when the sun rose, it was scorched, and because it had no root, it withered away.
And other seed fell among the thorns, and the thorns grew up and choked it, and it produced no grain.
And other seeds fell into the good soil and were yielding grain, growing up and increasing, and bearing thirty, sixty, and a hundredfold."
And he said, "Whoever has ears to hear, let them hear."
And when he was alone, those around him together with the Twelve were asking him about the parables.
And he said to them, "To you the mystery of the kingdom of God has been given. But to those outside, everything comes in parables,
so that seeing they may see but not perceive, and hearing they may hear but not understand—lest they turn back and be forgiven."
And he said to them, "You do not understand this parable? Then how will you understand all the parables?
The sower sows the word.
These are the ones along the path where the word is sown: when they hear, immediately Satan comes and takes away the word that was sown in them.
And these are the ones sown on rocky ground: when they hear the word, they immediately receive it with joy,
but they have no root in themselves; rather, they are temporary. Then when affliction or persecution arises because of the word, immediately they fall away.
And others are the ones sown among the thorns. These are the ones who hear the word,
but the anxieties of this age, and the seduction of wealth, and the cravings for everything else come in and choke the word, and it becomes unfruitful.
And these are the ones sown on the good soil: those who hear the word and welcome it and bear fruit—thirty, sixty, and a hundredfold."
And he said to them, "Does the lamp come to be put under the measuring basket, or under the bed? Does it not come to be put on the lampstand?
For nothing is hidden except to be revealed, nor has anything become secret except to come into the open.
If anyone has ears to hear, let them hear."
And he said to them, "Pay attention to what you hear. With the measure you use, it will be measured to you—and more will be added to you.
For whoever has, more will be given to them; and whoever does not have, even what they have will be taken from them."
And he said, "The kingdom of God is like this: as if a man should throw seed on the ground,
and should sleep and rise night and day, and the seed sprouts and grows—how, he himself does not know.
The earth produces fruit by itself: first the blade, then the head, then the full grain in the head.
But when the crop is ready, immediately he sends in the sickle, because the harvest has arrived."
And he said, "How shall we compare the kingdom of God, or with what parable shall we present it?
It is like a mustard seed, which when sown on the ground is the smallest of all the seeds on the earth—
yet when it is sown, it grows up and becomes the largest of all garden plants, and produces great branches, so that the birds of the sky can make nests in its shade."
With many such parables he was speaking the word to them, according to what they were able to hear.
Without a parable he did not speak to them, but privately to his own disciples he was explaining everything.
And he said to them on that day, when evening had come, "Let us cross to the other side."
And leaving the crowd, they took him along just as he was in the boat, and other boats were with him.
And a violent windstorm arose, and the waves were breaking into the boat, so that the boat was already filling up.
And he was in the stern, sleeping on the cushion. And they woke him and said to him, "Teacher, do you not care that we are perishing?"
And having risen, he rebuked the wind and said to the sea, "Silence! Be still!" And the wind ceased, and there was a great calm.
And he said to them, "Why are you so afraid? Do you still not have faith?"
And they were filled with great fear, and they said to one another, "Who then is this, that even the wind and the sea obey him?"

chapters.notes:
**"Mystery" (v. 11)**: Greek μυστήριον refers not to something puzzling but to a divine secret now being revealed to insiders. This is apocalyptic language—the hidden purposes of God are being disclosed to a chosen group.

**"So that...lest they turn back and be forgiven" (v. 12)**: The ἵνα clause presents a notorious interpretive challenge. Mark's Greek straightforwardly indicates purpose ("in order that"), citing Isaiah 6:9-10. Some scholars suggest the underlying Aramaic דִּלְמָא could mean "perhaps" rather than "lest," but Mark's Greek preserves the harder reading. I have translated it as Mark wrote it.

**"Temporary" (v. 17)**: Greek πρόσκαιροι means "for a season, lasting only a time"—describing people whose commitment is inherently impermanent, not just coincidentally brief.

**"Seduction of wealth" (v. 19)**: Greek ἀπάτη carries the sense of deception, enticement, and false allure—wealth's capacity to mislead about what matters.

**"Does the lamp come" (v. 21)**: The Greek personifies the lamp (ἔρχεται ὁ λύχνος)—it "comes" as if arriving with a purpose. This odd phrasing may hint that the "lamp" represents something (or someone) entering the scene with a mission.

**"Silence! Be still!" (v. 39)**: Σιώπα is a simple command for silence. But πεφίμωσο is a perfect passive imperative—"be muzzled and stay muzzled." Jesus speaks to the storm with the same commanding authority he uses against unclean spirits (the verb ἐπιτιμάω, "rebuke," is used for both). The sea's chaos is treated as a hostile force requiring subdual.

**"Great fear" (v. 41)**: The cognate construction ἐφοβήθησαν φόβον μέγαν (literally "they feared a great fear") emphasizes the overwhelming nature of their response. Ironically, Jesus had just asked why they were afraid (δειλοί); now they experience a deeper fear—the terror of encountering divine power.

verses.text: And they came to the other side of the sea, to the region of the Gerasenes.
And as he was getting out of the boat, immediately a man with an unclean spirit met him from among the tombs.
He had his dwelling among the tombs, and no one could bind him anymore—not even with a chain—
because he had often been bound with shackles and chains, and the chains had been torn apart by him and the shackles shattered, and no one had the strength to subdue him.
And continually, night and day, among the tombs and in the hills, he was crying out and gashing himself with stones.
And seeing Jesus from a distance, he ran and prostrated himself before him,
and crying out with a loud voice, he says, "What is there between you and me, Jesus, Son of the Most High God? I adjure you by God—do not torment me!"
For he had been saying to him, "Come out of the man, unclean spirit!"
And he asked him, "What is your name?" And he says to him, "Legion is my name, because we are many."
And he begged him urgently not to send them out of the region.
Now there was a large herd of pigs there, feeding on the hillside.
And they begged him, saying, "Send us into the pigs, so that we may enter them."
And he permitted them. And the unclean spirits came out and entered the pigs, and the herd—about two thousand—charged down the steep bank into the sea and were drowning in the sea.
And those tending them fled and reported it in the town and in the countryside. And people came to see what had happened.
And they come to Jesus and see the demonized man sitting there, clothed and in his right mind—the one who had had the legion—and they were afraid.
And those who had seen it described to them how it had happened to the demonized man, and about the pigs.
And they began to beg him to leave their territory.
And as he was getting into the boat, the man who had been demonized begged him that he might be with him.
But he did not permit him. Instead he says to him, "Go to your home, to your own people, and report to them what the Lord has done for you and how he had mercy on you."
And he went away and began to proclaim in the Decapolis what Jesus had done for him, and everyone was amazed.
And when Jesus had crossed again in the boat to the other side, a large crowd gathered around him, and he was beside the sea.
And one of the synagogue leaders comes, named Jairus, and seeing him, he falls at his feet
and begs him urgently, saying, "My little daughter is at death's door. Come and lay your hands on her so that she may be healed and live."
And he went with him. And a large crowd was following him and pressing in on him.
And a woman who had had a flow of blood for twelve years—
and had suffered much under many physicians and had spent everything she had and had not been helped at all but rather had grown worse—
having heard about Jesus, came up behind him in the crowd and touched his garment.
For she had been saying to herself, "If I just touch his clothes, I will be healed."
And immediately the source of her blood dried up, and she knew in her body that she was healed from her affliction.
And immediately Jesus, perceiving within himself that power had gone out from him, turned around in the crowd and said, "Who touched my clothes?"
And his disciples said to him, "You see the crowd pressing in on you, and you say, 'Who touched me?'"
But he kept looking around to see the woman who had done this.
And the woman, afraid and trembling, knowing what had happened to her, came and fell down before him and told him the whole truth.
And he said to her, "Daughter, your faith has saved you. Go in peace, and be healed from your affliction."
While he was still speaking, people come from the synagogue leader's house, saying, "Your daughter has died. Why trouble the teacher any further?"
But Jesus, disregarding the message being spoken, says to the synagogue leader, "Do not be afraid—only trust."
And he did not permit anyone to accompany him except Peter and James and John, the brother of James.
And they come to the house of the synagogue leader, and he sees a commotion—people weeping and wailing loudly.
And entering, he says to them, "Why are you in an uproar and weeping? The child has not died but is sleeping."
And they laughed at him. But he, having put them all outside, takes the child's father and mother and those who were with him, and goes in where the child was.
And grasping the child by the hand, he says to her, "Talitha koum"—which means, "Little girl, I say to you, rise."
And immediately the girl stood up and began walking around—for she was twelve years old—and immediately they were utterly astounded.
And he strictly ordered them that no one should know about this, and told them to give her something to eat.

chapters.notes:
**"What is there between you and me" (v. 7)**: The Greek τί ἐμοὶ καὶ σοί is a Semitic idiom (literally "what to me and to you?") that marks distance or conflict between parties. "What do you have to do with me?" is common but slightly misses the bidirectional nature of the idiom.

**"Adjure" (v. 7)**: ὁρκίζω means to put someone under oath or bind them by an oath. The demon attempts to use oath-language against Jesus—a striking reversal.

**"Legion" (v. 9)**: A Roman military term for a unit of 5,000-6,000 soldiers. The term carries political resonance in occupied territory; the unclean spirits identify themselves with the vocabulary of imperial occupation.

**"Subdue" (v. 4)**: δαμάσαι literally means "to tame," as one tames a wild animal. This language characterizes the man as having become like a wild beast.

**"Prostrated himself" (v. 6)**: προσεκύνησεν can mean worship or obeisance; the ambiguity may be intentional—the demons recognize Jesus's divine authority even as they resist it.

**"The Lord...Jesus" (vv. 19-20)**: Jesus tells the man to proclaim what "the Lord" (ὁ κύριος) has done; the man proclaims what "Jesus" has done. Mark lets readers draw the connection.

**"At death's door" (v. 23)**: ἐσχάτως ἔχει literally means "is at the last" or "is at the extremity"—an idiom for being at the point of death.

**"Saved/healed" (vv. 23, 28, 34)**: σῴζω carries both meanings. In verse 34, "your faith has saved you" deliberately encompasses both physical healing and spiritual restoration.

**"Affliction" (vv. 29, 34)**: μάστιξ literally means "whip" or "scourge," used metaphorically for a severe affliction. "Disease" is too clinical; "affliction" preserves the sense of suffering.

**"Disregarding" (v. 36)**: παρακούσας can mean either "overhearing" or "ignoring/disregarding." Given the context—Jesus responds by telling Jairus not to fear—"disregarding" better captures Jesus's deliberate dismissal of the death announcement.

**"Trust" (v. 36)**: πίστευε is often rendered "believe," but in this context the call is for active trust in Jesus's power despite the report of death.

**"Talitha koum" (v. 41)**: Mark preserves the Aramaic Jesus actually spoke. Ταλιθα is an Aramaic term of endearment for a young girl (literally "lamb" or "little girl"); κουμ is the imperative "arise/get up."

**Twelve years (vv. 25, 42)**: The woman has suffered for twelve years; the girl is twelve years old. Mark's juxtaposition seems deliberate—the girl's entire life spans the duration of the woman's affliction.

verses.text: And he went out from there and comes to his hometown, and his disciples follow him.

When the Sabbath came, he began to teach in the synagogue, and the many who heard him were struck with astonishment, saying, "Where did this man get these things? And what is this wisdom that has been given to him? And such powerful deeds done through his hands!
Is this not the craftsman, the son of Mary and brother of James and Joses and Judas and Simon? And are not his sisters here with us?" And they took offense at him.
And Jesus said to them, "A prophet is not without honor except in his hometown, and among his relatives, and in his own household."
And he was unable to do any powerful deed there, except that he laid his hands on a few sick people and healed them.
And he was amazed at their unbelief. And he went around the surrounding villages teaching.
And he summons the twelve and began to send them out two by two, and he gave them authority over the unclean spirits.
And he instructed them to take nothing for the journey except a staff only—no bread, no bag, no copper coins in the belt—
but to wear sandals and not to put on two tunics.
And he said to them, "Wherever you enter a house, remain there until you leave that place.
And whatever place does not welcome you or listen to you, as you leave there, shake off the dust from under your feet as a testimony against them."
And they went out and proclaimed that people should turn back,
and they were casting out many demons and anointing many sick people with oil and healing them.
And King Herod heard of it, for his name had become well known, and people were saying, "John the baptizer has been raised from the dead, and because of this the powers are at work in him."
But others were saying, "It is Elijah." And others were saying, "A prophet, like one of the prophets."
But when Herod heard, he kept saying, "John, whom I beheaded—this one has been raised."
For Herod himself had sent men to arrest John and bound him in prison on account of Herodias, the wife of his brother Philip, because he had married her.
For John had been telling Herod, "It is not lawful for you to have your brother's wife."
And Herodias harbored a grudge against him and wanted to kill him, but she was not able,
for Herod feared John, knowing him to be a righteous and holy man, and he kept him safe. And when he heard him, he was greatly perplexed, yet he listened to him gladly.
But an opportune day came when Herod on his birthday gave a banquet for his nobles and military commanders and the leading men of Galilee.

And when the daughter of Herodias herself came in and danced, she pleased Herod and those reclining at table with him. The king said to the girl, "Ask me for whatever you want, and I will give it to you."
And he swore to her, "Whatever you ask me, I will give you—up to half my kingdom."
And going out she said to her mother, "What should I ask for?" And she said, "The head of John the baptizer."
And coming in immediately with haste to the king, she made her request, saying, "I want you to give me at once the head of John the Baptist on a platter."
And though the king became deeply grieved, because of his oaths and those reclining at table he did not want to refuse her.
And immediately the king sent an executioner and commanded him to bring his head. And he went and beheaded him in the prison
and brought his head on a platter and gave it to the girl, and the girl gave it to her mother.
And when his disciples heard, they came and took his corpse and laid it in a tomb.
And the apostles gather to Jesus and reported to him all that they had done and all that they had taught.
And he says to them, "Come away by yourselves to a deserted place and rest a while." For there were many coming and going, and they had no opportunity even to eat.
And they went away in the boat to a deserted place by themselves.
But many saw them going and recognized them, and they ran there on foot from all the towns and arrived ahead of them.
And when he got out, he saw a great crowd, and his heart went out to them because they were like sheep without a shepherd. And he began to teach them many things.
And when the hour was already late, his disciples came to him and said, "This place is deserted and the hour is already late.
Send them away so that they can go into the surrounding countryside and villages and buy themselves something to eat."
But he answered them, "You give them something to eat." And they say to him, "Should we go and buy two hundred denarii worth of bread and give it to them to eat?"
And he says to them, "How many loaves do you have? Go and see." And when they found out, they say, "Five—and two fish."
And he ordered them to have everyone recline in dining groups on the green grass.
And they sat down in garden plots, in groups of a hundred and groups of fifty.

And taking the five loaves and the two fish, he looked up to heaven and blessed and broke the loaves and kept giving them to his disciples to set before the people. And the two fish he divided among them all.
And everyone ate and was satisfied.
And they picked up twelve baskets full of broken pieces, and also from the fish.
And those who ate the loaves were five thousand men.
And immediately he made his disciples get into the boat and go ahead to the other side, toward Bethsaida, while he himself dismisses the crowd.
And after taking leave of them, he went up on the mountain to pray.
And when evening came, the boat was in the middle of the sea, and he was alone on the land.
And seeing them straining at the oars—for the wind was against them—around the fourth watch of the night he comes to them, walking on the sea. And he intended to pass by them.
But when they saw him walking on the sea, they thought it was a ghost and cried out,
for they all saw him and were terrified. But immediately he spoke with them and says to them, "Take courage! I am. Do not be afraid."
And he got into the boat with them, and the wind ceased. And they were utterly astounded within themselves,
for they had not understood about the loaves—rather, their hearts were hardened.
And having crossed over, they came to land at Gennesaret and moored the boat.
And when they got out of the boat, immediately people recognized him
and ran about that whole region and began to carry around on mats those who were ill to wherever they heard he was.

And wherever he went—into villages or cities or countryside—they laid the sick in the marketplaces and begged him that they might touch even the fringe of his garment. And as many as touched it were healed.

chapters.notes:
**"Craftsman" (v. 3)**: Greek τέκτων is traditionally rendered "carpenter," but the term is broader—a worker in wood, stone, or other building materials. "Craftsman" better captures this range while remaining natural.

**"Took offense" (v. 3)**: ἐσκανδαλίζοντο literally means "were caused to stumble." The scandal is that Jesus's ordinary origins are a stumbling block to accepting his teaching and power.

**"Turn back" (v. 12)**: μετανοέω is typically rendered "repent," but this can sound purely religious to modern ears. The Greek denotes a fundamental change of mind and direction—turning back toward God.

**"His heart went out to them" (v. 34)**: ἐσπλαγχνίσθη derives from σπλάγχνα (internal organs), understood as the seat of deep emotion. "Moved with compassion" is accurate but clinical; "his heart went out" captures the visceral quality.

**"Sheep without a shepherd" (v. 34)**: This phrase echoes Numbers 27:17 and Ezekiel 34, where Israel's leaders have failed the people. Mark's audience would recognize this as a loaded image of divine judgment on failed leadership.

**"Dining groups...garden plots" (vv. 39-40)**: The Greek uses distributive reduplication: συμπόσια συμπόσια (group by group) and πρασιαὶ πρασιαὶ (literally "garden bed by garden bed"). The visual effect is an orderly arrangement on the green grass, evoking a garden scene.

**"He intended to pass by them" (v. 48)**: ἤθελεν παρελθεῖν is puzzling if taken at face value. However, "passing by" echoes Old Testament theophanies where God "passes by" his servants (Exodus 33:19-22; 1 Kings 19:11). This may signal a divine self-revelation.

**"I am" (v. 50)**: ἐγώ εἰμι functions grammatically as "It is I," but in context—walking on water, passing by, calming the storm—the echo of the divine name (Exodus 3:14) is likely intentional. I have left it unresolved as "I am" to preserve the ambiguity present in the Greek.

**"Their hearts were hardened" (v. 52)**: πεπωρωμένη means calloused or petrified. The same term describes Pharaoh's heart in the Septuagint. Mark applies it startlingly to the disciples themselves.

verses.text: The Pharisees gathered around him, along with some of the scribes who had come from Jerusalem.
They noticed that some of his disciples were eating their food with defiled hands—that is, unwashed.
(For the Pharisees and all the Judeans do not eat unless they wash their hands thoroughly, holding to the tradition of the elders.

And when they come from the marketplace, they do not eat unless they wash themselves. There are many other things they have received and hold to: the immersion of cups and pitchers and bronze vessels and dining couches.)
So the Pharisees and the scribes questioned him: "Why do your disciples not conduct themselves according to the tradition of the elders, but instead eat their food with defiled hands?"
He said to them: "Isaiah prophesied well about you performers, as it is written: 'This people honors me with their lips, but their heart is far distant from me.
They worship me in vain, teaching as doctrines the commandments of human beings.'
Having abandoned the commandment of God, you hold fast to the tradition of human beings."
And he said to them: "How expertly you set aside the commandment of God in order to keep your own tradition!
For Moses said, 'Honor your father and your mother,' and, 'Whoever speaks evil of father or mother must surely die.'
But you say: If a person says to his father or mother, 'Corban'—which means 'Gift to God'—'is what you might have received from me,'
you no longer permit him to do anything for his father or mother.
You invalidate the word of God by your tradition that you have handed down. And you do many similar things."
Then, summoning the crowd again, he said to them: "Listen to me, all of you, and understand.
There is nothing outside a person that by going into them can defile them. Rather, the things that come out of a person are what defile the person."
When he had gone into a house away from the crowd, his disciples asked him about the riddle.
He said to them: "Are you also so lacking in understanding? Do you not grasp that nothing entering a person from outside can defile them,
because it does not enter into the heart but into the stomach, and goes out into the latrine?"—thus declaring all foods clean.
And he said: "What comes out of a person—that is what defiles the person.
For from within, out of the human heart, come evil schemes: sexual immoralities, thefts, murders,
adulteries, acts of greed, malicious deeds, deceit, shameless indulgence, the envious eye, slander, arrogance, foolishness.
All these evils come from within and defile the person."
Rising from there, he went away to the region of Tyre. He entered a house and wanted no one to know, but he could not escape notice.
Immediately a woman whose little daughter had an unclean spirit heard about him and came and fell at his feet.
Now the woman was a Greek, a Syrophoenician by ethnicity. She kept asking him to drive the demon out of her daughter.
He said to her: "Let the children be fed first, for it is not right to take the children's bread and throw it to the little dogs."
But she answered him: "Lord, even the little dogs under the table eat from the children's crumbs."
He said to her: "Because of this word, go—the demon has left your daughter."
She went home and found the child lying on the bed, and the demon gone.
Then departing again from the region of Tyre, he went through Sidon to the Sea of Galilee, through the middle of the Decapolis region.
They brought to him a man who was deaf and could barely speak, and they urged him to lay his hand on him.
Taking him aside from the crowd privately, he put his fingers into the man's ears, and after spitting, touched his tongue.
Then looking up to heaven, he sighed deeply and said to him, "Ephphatha!"—which means, "Be opened!"
And his ears were opened, the binding on his tongue was released, and he began speaking plainly.
Jesus ordered them to tell no one. But the more he ordered them, the more abundantly they proclaimed it.
They were astonished beyond all measure, saying, "He has done everything well—he makes the deaf hear and the mute speak!"

chapters.notes:
**"Defiled hands" (vv. 2, 5)**: The Greek κοιναῖς means "common" in the sense of ritually impure—contaminated by contact with what is profane. "Defiled" captures the ritual pollution concept better than "unclean," which in modern English suggests mere dirtiness.

**"Performers" (v. 6)**: Greek ὑποκριτῶν. As with the Matthew 6 example, this preserves the theatrical sense—people whose religion is a public act rather than heart-disposition.

**"Conduct themselves" (v. 5)**: Greek περιπατοῦσιν literally means "walk," but idiomatically refers to one's manner of life or conduct. This was a standard Jewish metaphor (halakah comes from the Hebrew for "walk").

**"Thoroughly" (v. 3)**: The Greek πυγμῇ is notoriously difficult—literally "with the fist." Interpretations range from a specific washing technique to an idiom meaning "diligently." I've chosen "thoroughly" to convey the sense of careful observance without committing to a specific physical gesture.

**"Thus declaring all foods clean" (v. 19)**: The masculine participle καθαρίζων doesn't grammatically agree with anything in the immediate clause. Most scholars read this as Mark's editorial comment, explaining the implications of Jesus's teaching for his Gentile audience. The translation makes this parenthetical function clear.

**"Evil schemes" (v. 21)**: Greek διαλογισμοί refers to inner reasonings, calculations, or deliberations—the planning that precedes action. "Thoughts" is too passive; these are active mental machinations.

**"The envious eye" (v. 22)**: Greek ὀφθαλμὸς πονηρός is a Semitic idiom for envy or stinginess (compare Matthew 20:15). Rendering it literally preserves the idiom, which would have been recognized by readers familiar with Jewish expression.

**"Could barely speak" (v. 32)**: Greek μογιλάλον appears only here in the NT and in Isaiah 35:6 LXX, where the prophet promises that "the tongue of the mute will sing for joy." Mark's rare word choice likely signals this prophetic fulfillment.

**"He has done everything well" (v. 37)**: This echoes Genesis 1:31 LXX ("God saw everything that he had made, and behold, it was very good/καλά"). The crowd unknowingly declares Jesus's work to be a new creation.

verses.text: In those days, when again there was a large crowd with nothing to eat, he summoned his disciples and says to them,
"I am moved with compassion for this crowd, because they have already stayed with me three days and have nothing to eat.
And if I send them away hungry to their homes, they will collapse on the way—and some of them have come from far away."
His disciples answered him, "Where could anyone get enough bread to satisfy these people here in this desolate place?"
And he asked them, "How many loaves do you have?" They said, "Seven."
And he commands the crowd to sit down on the ground. Taking the seven loaves and giving thanks, he broke them and kept giving them to his disciples to serve, and they served them to the crowd.
They also had a few small fish. And blessing them, he said to serve these as well.
And they ate and were satisfied, and they collected seven large baskets of leftover fragments.
There were about four thousand. And he sent them away.
And immediately, getting into the boat with his disciples, he went to the region of Dalmanutha.
The Pharisees came out and began to argue with him, demanding from him a sign from heaven, testing him.
And sighing deeply in his spirit, he says, "Why does this generation demand a sign? Truly I tell you—no sign will be given to this generation."
And leaving them, he got back into the boat and departed for the other side.
Now they had forgotten to bring bread, and except for one loaf they had nothing with them in the boat.
And he was warning them, saying, "Watch out! Beware of the leaven of the Pharisees and the leaven of Herod."
And they were discussing with one another that they had no bread.
And perceiving this, he says to them, "Why are you discussing that you have no bread? Do you still not understand or comprehend? Are your hearts hardened?
Having eyes, do you not see? Having ears, do you not hear? And do you not remember?
When I broke the five loaves for the five thousand, how many baskets full of fragments did you collect?" They say to him, "Twelve."
"And the seven for the four thousand—how many large baskets full of fragments did you collect?" And they say to him, "Seven."
And he was saying to them, "Do you still not understand?"
And they come to Bethsaida. And they bring a blind man to him and beg him to touch him.
Taking hold of the blind man's hand, he led him outside the village. And spitting on his eyes and laying his hands on him, he asked him, "Do you see anything?"
And looking up, he said, "I see people—but I see them like trees, walking around."
Then again he laid his hands on his eyes, and he saw clearly and was restored and could see everything distinctly.
And he sent him to his home, saying, "Do not even enter the village."
And Jesus went out with his disciples to the villages of Caesarea Philippi. And on the way he was asking his disciples, saying to them, "Who do people say that I am?"
And they told him, "John the Baptizer; others say Elijah; and still others, one of the prophets."
And he asked them, "But you—who do you say that I am?" Peter answered and says to him, "You are the Messiah."
And he sternly warned them to tell no one about him.
And he began to teach them that the Son of Man must suffer many things and be rejected by the elders and the chief priests and the scribes, and be killed, and after three days rise.
And he was speaking this word openly. And Peter, taking him aside, began to rebuke him.
But turning around and seeing his disciples, he rebuked Peter and says, "Get behind me, Satan! For you are not thinking the things of God, but the things of humans."
And summoning the crowd together with his disciples, he said to them, "If anyone wants to come after me, let him deny himself and take up his cross and follow me.
For whoever wants to save his life will lose it, but whoever loses his life for my sake and the gospel's will save it.
For what does it profit a person to gain the whole world and forfeit his life?
For what could a person give in exchange for his life?
For whoever is ashamed of me and my words in this adulterous and sinful generation, the Son of Man will also be ashamed of him when he comes in the glory of his Father with the holy angels."

chapters.notes:
**"I am moved with compassion" (v. 2)**: The Greek σπλαγχνίζομαι derives from σπλάγχνα (internal organs, bowels), expressing a visceral, gut-level emotion. This is stronger than merely "feeling sorry for"—it's a deep, physical experience of compassion.

**"No sign will be given" (v. 12)**: The Greek εἰ δοθήσεται is a Semitic oath formula where the apodosis is suppressed: "May God do X to me if a sign is given..." The construction functions as an emphatic denial, which I have rendered directly rather than preserving the elliptical grammar.

**Two words for baskets (vv. 8, 19-20)**: Mark distinguishes between κόφινοι (v. 19, the feeding of the 5,000) and σπυρίδες (vv. 8, 20, the feeding of the 4,000). The σπυρίς was a larger basket, sometimes large enough to hold a person (cf. Acts 9:25). I use "baskets" and "large baskets" to preserve this distinction, which Jesus emphasizes in his questioning.

**"Having eyes, do you not see?" (v. 18)**: This echoes Jeremiah 5:21 and Ezekiel 12:2 from the Septuagint. The original audience would recognize this prophetic indictment of Israel's spiritual blindness, which then sets up the two-stage healing of the blind man as a commentary on the disciples' gradual understanding.

**"The Messiah" (v. 29)**: Greek χριστός translates Hebrew משיח ("anointed one"). For a first-century Jewish audience, this title carried specific expectations of a royal deliverer. "Messiah" preserves this resonance better than the now-generic "Christ."

**"Adulterous" (v. 38)**: Greek μοιχαλίδι uses the prophetic metaphor of adultery for spiritual unfaithfulness to God (cf. Hosea, Jeremiah, Ezekiel). This is not about sexual morality but about covenant betrayal—the generation has been unfaithful to Israel's God.

**Historic present tense**: Mark frequently uses the present tense for vivid narration (λέγει, "he says"). I have preserved this where it appears in the Greek rather than smoothing it to past tense, as it captures Mark's characteristic immediacy.

**"Life" vs. "soul" (vv. 35-37)**: Greek ψυχή means one's life, self, or whole existence—not the disembodied "soul" of later Greek philosophy. In this context, Jesus is talking about one's entire life and identity, which "life" captures better for modern readers.

verses.text: And he was saying to them: "Truly I tell you, there are some of those standing here who will certainly not taste death until they see the kingdom of God having come in power."
And after six days, Jesus takes Peter and James and John and leads them up a high mountain, by themselves, alone. And he was transformed before them,
and his garments became dazzling—intensely white, such as no launderer on earth could whiten them.
And Elijah appeared to them, with Moses, and they were conversing with Jesus.
And Peter, responding, says to Jesus: "Rabbi, it is good for us to be here! Let us make three shelters—one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elijah."
For he did not know what to say, for they had become terrified.
And a cloud came, overshadowing them, and a voice came from the cloud: "This is my Son, the Beloved—listen to him!"
And suddenly, looking around, they no longer saw anyone, but only Jesus with them.
And as they were coming down from the mountain, he ordered them to relate to no one what they had seen, except when the Son of Man has risen from the dead.
And they kept the matter to themselves, debating among themselves what this "rising from the dead" meant.
And they were asking him: "Why do the scribes say that Elijah must come first?"
And he said to them: "Elijah indeed comes first and restores all things. Yet how is it written concerning the Son of Man? That he must suffer many things and be treated as nothing.
But I tell you that Elijah has indeed come, and they did to him whatever they wanted, just as it is written concerning him."
And when they came to the disciples, they saw a large crowd around them and scribes arguing with them.
And immediately, when all the crowd saw him, they were utterly amazed, and running up to him, they greeted him.
And he asked them: "What are you arguing about with them?"
And one from the crowd answered him: "Teacher, I brought my son to you—he has a mute spirit.
And wherever it seizes him, it throws him down, and he foams at the mouth and grinds his teeth and becomes rigid. I asked your disciples to cast it out, and they were not strong enough."
And answering them, he says: "O faithless generation! How long must I be with you? How long must I bear with you? Bring him to me."
And they brought him to him. And when the spirit saw him, it immediately threw him into convulsions, and falling on the ground, he was rolling around, foaming at the mouth.
And Jesus asked his father: "How long has this been happening to him?" And he said: "From childhood.
And many times it has thrown him both into fire and into water to destroy him. But if you can do anything, have compassion on us and help us."
And Jesus said to him: "'If you can'!—All things are possible for the one who believes."
Immediately the father of the child cried out: "I believe! Help my unbelief!"
And when Jesus saw that a crowd was running together toward them, he rebuked the unclean spirit, saying to it: "Mute and deaf spirit—I command you: come out of him and never again enter him."
And after crying out and convulsing him violently, it came out. And he became like a corpse, so that many were saying, "He has died."
But Jesus, grasping his hand, raised him, and he rose.
And when he had gone into a house, his disciples asked him privately: "Why were we not able to cast it out?"
And he said to them: "This kind can come out by nothing except prayer."
And leaving there, they were passing through Galilee, and he did not want anyone to know,
for he was teaching his disciples. And he was telling them: "The Son of Man is being handed over into human hands, and they will kill him, and after being killed, after three days he will rise."
But they did not understand the saying, and they were afraid to ask him.
And they came to Capernaum. And when he was in the house, he asked them: "What were you discussing on the way?"
But they were silent, for on the way they had been arguing with one another about who was greatest.
And sitting down, he called the twelve and says to them: "If anyone wants to be first, he must be last of all and servant of all."
And taking a child, he set him in their midst, and taking him in his arms, he said to them:
"Whoever receives one such child in my name receives me. And whoever receives me receives not me but the one who sent me."
John said to him: "Teacher, we saw someone casting out demons in your name, and we tried to stop him, because he was not following us."
But Jesus said: "Do not stop him. For there is no one who will do a mighty work in my name and then be able soon afterward to speak evil of me.
For whoever is not against us is for us.
For whoever gives you a cup of water to drink because you belong to Christ—truly I tell you, he will certainly not lose his reward.
"And whoever causes one of these little ones who believe in me to stumble—it would be better for him if a millstone turned by a donkey were hung around his neck and he were thrown into the sea.
"And if your hand causes you to stumble, cut it off. It is better for you to enter life maimed than with two hands to go away into Gehenna, into the unquenchable fire.
And if your foot causes you to stumble, cut it off. It is better for you to enter life lame than with two feet to be thrown into Gehenna.
And if your eye causes you to stumble, tear it out. It is better for you to enter the kingdom of God with one eye than with two eyes to be thrown into Gehenna,
'where their worm does not die and the fire is not quenched.'
"For everyone will be salted with fire.
Salt is good. But if salt becomes saltless, with what will you season it? Have salt in yourselves, and be at peace with one another."

chapters.notes:
**"Transformed" (v. 2)**: The Greek μετεμορφώθη is the root of English "metamorphosis." While "transfigured" is the traditional rendering and carries appropriate theological weight, "transformed" captures the essential meaning—a change in form—without the ecclesiastical overtones that might obscure the strange physicality Mark describes.

**"Dazzling" (v. 3)**: The Greek στίλβοντα means gleaming, flashing, radiant. Combined with λίαν (exceedingly), this conveys something more dramatic than merely "white." The comparison to a launderer (γναφεύς—one who bleaches and fulls cloth) emphasizes the otherworldly nature: this whiteness exceeds any human achievement.

**"Treated as nothing" (v. 12)**: The Greek ἐξουδενηθῇ means to be utterly rejected, despised, treated as worthless. "Rejected" (common in translations) is too mild; the word conveys contemptuous dismissal.

**"Becomes rigid" (v. 18)**: The Greek ξηραίνεται literally means "dries up" or "withers," but in this context describes the stiffening characteristic of severe seizures—the body going rigid.

**"'If you can'!" (v. 23)**: The Greek construction τὸ Εἰ δύνῃ uses the article to quote back the father's words. Jesus is highlighting the conditional as problematic—hence the rendering with quotation marks and exclamation.

**"Raised him, and he rose" (v. 27)**: The verbs ἤγειρεν and ἀνέστη are the standard vocabulary for resurrection. Mark may be deliberately evoking resurrection imagery in this healing that follows the boy becoming "like a corpse."

**"Millstone turned by a donkey" (v. 42)**: The Greek μύλος ὀνικός specifies the large millstone requiring a donkey to turn it, as opposed to a small hand-mill. This emphasizes the weight—drowning would be certain and immediate.

**"Gehenna" (vv. 43, 45, 47)**: I retain "Gehenna" rather than "hell" because the latter has accumulated centuries of imagery foreign to the original reference—the Valley of Hinnom outside Jerusalem, associated with fire and refuse, and in Jewish tradition with final judgment.

**Verse numbering (vv. 44, 46 omitted)**: Following the critical text, which lacks verses 44 and 46—later manuscripts added these by repeating v. 48 after each warning.

**"Because you belong to Christ" (v. 41)**: The Greek ἐν ὀνόματι ὅτι χριστοῦ ἐστε is literally "in the name that you are of Christ." This is one of the few places in Mark where "Christ" appears as a title the disciples are identified with.

verses.text: And rising from there, he comes into the region of Judea and beyond the Jordan, and crowds again gather around him, and as was his custom he again began teaching them.
And some Pharisees approached and asked him whether it is lawful for a man to divorce his wife—testing him.
He answered and said to them, "What did Moses command you?"
They said, "Moses permitted writing a certificate of separation and divorcing her."
But Jesus said to them, "It was because of your hard-heartedness that he wrote you this commandment.
But from the beginning of creation, 'male and female he made them.'
'For this reason a man will leave his father and mother and be joined to his wife,
and the two will become one flesh.' So they are no longer two but one flesh.
Therefore, what God has yoked together, let no human separate."
And in the house again, the disciples were asking him about this.
And he says to them, "Whoever divorces his wife and marries another commits adultery against her.
And if she, having divorced her husband, marries another, she commits adultery."
And people were bringing children to him so that he might touch them, but the disciples rebuked them.
When Jesus saw this, he was indignant and said to them, "Let the children come to me—stop hindering them—for the kingdom of God belongs to such as these.
Truly I tell you, whoever does not receive the kingdom of God like a child will never enter it."
And taking them in his arms, he blessed them, laying his hands on them.
And as he was setting out on the road, a man ran up and knelt before him and asked him, "Good Teacher, what must I do to inherit eternal life?"
Jesus said to him, "Why do you call me good? No one is good except God alone.
You know the commandments: 'Do not murder, Do not commit adultery, Do not steal, Do not give false testimony, Do not defraud, Honor your father and mother.'"
He said to him, "Teacher, all these I have kept since my youth."
Jesus, looking at him intently, loved him and said to him, "One thing you lack: go, sell whatever you have and give to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven—then come, follow me."
But his face fell at these words, and he went away grieving, for he had many possessions.
And Jesus, looking around, says to his disciples, "How hard it will be for those who have wealth to enter the kingdom of God!"
The disciples were astounded at his words. But Jesus, responding again, says to them, "Children, how hard it is to enter the kingdom of God!
It is easier for a camel to pass through the eye of a needle than for a rich person to enter the kingdom of God."
They were utterly astonished, saying to one another, "Then who can be saved?"
Jesus, looking at them, says, "With humans it is impossible, but not with God—for all things are possible with God."
Peter began to say to him, "Look, we have left everything and followed you."
Jesus said, "Truly I tell you, there is no one who has left house or brothers or sisters or mother or father or children or fields for my sake and for the sake of the good news
who will not receive a hundredfold now in this present time—houses and brothers and sisters and mothers and children and fields, along with persecutions—and in the age to come, eternal life.
But many who are first will be last, and the last first."

Now they were on the road going up to Jerusalem, and Jesus was walking ahead of them, and they were amazed, and those following were afraid. Taking the Twelve aside again, he began to tell them what was about to happen to him:
"Look, we are going up to Jerusalem, and the Son of Man will be handed over to the chief priests and the scribes, and they will condemn him to death and hand him over to the Gentiles,
and they will mock him and spit on him and flog him and kill him, and after three days he will rise."
And James and John, the sons of Zebedee, approach him, saying, "Teacher, we want you to do for us whatever we ask of you."
He said to them, "What do you want me to do for you?"
They said to him, "Grant us to sit, one at your right hand and one at your left, in your glory."
Jesus said to them, "You do not know what you are asking. Can you drink the cup that I am drinking, or be baptized with the baptism with which I am being baptized?"
They said to him, "We can." Jesus said to them, "The cup that I am drinking you will drink, and the baptism with which I am being baptized, you will be baptized with.
But to sit at my right or at my left is not mine to give; it is for those for whom it has been prepared."
When the ten heard this, they began to be indignant about James and John.
And summoning them, Jesus says to them, "You know that those who are recognized as rulers of the nations lord it over them, and their great ones wield authority over them.
But it is not so among you. Rather, whoever wants to become great among you must be your servant,
and whoever wants to be first among you must be slave of all.
For even the Son of Man did not come to be served but to serve, and to give his life as a ransom in exchange for many."
And they come to Jericho. And as he was leaving Jericho with his disciples and a considerable crowd, the son of Timaeus, Bartimaeus, a blind beggar, was sitting beside the road.
When he heard that it was Jesus the Nazarene, he began to cry out and say, "Son of David, Jesus, have mercy on me!"
Many were rebuking him, telling him to be silent, but he cried out all the more, "Son of David, have mercy on me!"
Jesus stopped and said, "Call him." And they call the blind man, saying to him, "Take courage! Get up, he is calling you."
Throwing off his cloak, he sprang up and came to Jesus.
And Jesus responded to him, "What do you want me to do for you?" The blind man said to him, "Rabbouni, let me see again."
And Jesus said to him, "Go, your faith has healed you." And immediately he could see again, and he followed him on the road.

chapters.notes:
**"Certificate of separation" (v. 4)**: The Greek βιβλίον ἀποστασίου is literally "document of standing apart/away." "Separation" captures this more directly than the traditional "divorce," though it means the same thing legally.

**"Yoked together" (v. 9)**: The Greek συνέζευξεν specifically evokes the image of joining under a yoke—two animals joined as one working unit. This agricultural metaphor adds concrete imagery that "joined" lacks.

**"Commits adultery against her" (v. 11)**: The ἐπ' αὐτήν ("against her") is significant and often softened in translation. Jesus portrays the first wife as the wronged party—a striking view in a context where adultery was typically conceived as a wrong against another man whose wife was violated.

**"His face fell" (v. 22)**: The verb στυγνάσας describes a darkening or clouding of the countenance—the visible physical expression of inner distress. "His face fell" captures this better than the more abstract "he was sad."

**"Do not defraud" (v. 19)**: Μὴ ἀποστερήσῃς is not part of the Decalogue. Its inclusion here seems pointedly relevant to a wealthy person—a command against economic exploitation.

**"Those who are recognized as rulers" (v. 42)**: The Greek οἱ δοκοῦντες ἄρχειν has a subtle edge—"those who seem to rule" or "those reputed to rule." This may hint that such authority is more apparent than real, or simply be a standard idiom for recognized leaders.

**"Ransom in exchange for" (v. 45)**: The Greek λύτρον ἀντὶ πολλῶν uses commercial/redemption language. A λύτρον is the price paid to secure release (of a slave, prisoner, or captive), and ἀντί indicates substitution or exchange.

**"Rabbouni" (v. 51)**: Retained in Aramaic as Mark does. This is an intensified or more personal form of "Rabbi"—"my master" or "my teacher." The blind man's use of this intimate address contrasts with his earlier public cries of "Son of David."

**"Healed you" / "see again" (vv. 51-52)**: The verb σῴζω can mean both "save" and "heal." In this context of physical restoration, "healed" is primary. The verb ἀναβλέπω means specifically "to see again" or "to recover sight," implying Bartimaeus was not born blind.

verses.text: And as they draw near to Jerusalem, to Bethphage and Bethany at the Mount of Olives, he sends two of his disciples
and tells them, "Go into the village ahead of you, and immediately as you enter it you will find a colt tied up on which no human being has ever sat. Untie it and bring it.
And if anyone says to you, 'Why are you doing this?' say, 'The Lord has need of it and will send it back here right away.'"
They went off and found a colt tied at a door outside on the street, and they untie it.
Some of those standing there said to them, "What are you doing, untying the colt?"
They answered just as Jesus had said, and the people let them go.
They bring the colt to Jesus and throw their cloaks over it, and he sat on it.
Many spread their cloaks on the road, while others spread leafy branches they had cut from the fields.
Those going ahead and those following were crying out: "Hosanna! Blessed is the one coming in the name of the Lord!
Blessed is the coming kingdom of our father David! Hosanna in the highest heavens!"
And he entered Jerusalem and went into the temple. After looking around at everything, since the hour was already late, he went out to Bethany with the Twelve.
On the next day, as they were leaving Bethany, he became hungry.

Seeing a fig tree in the distance with leaves on it, he went to see if perhaps he might find something on it. But when he came to it he found nothing except leaves, for it was not the season for figs.
He spoke and said to it, "May no one ever eat fruit from you again." And his disciples were listening.

They come to Jerusalem. And entering the temple, he began driving out those selling and those buying in the temple, and he overturned the tables of the money-changers and the seats of those selling doves.
He would not permit anyone to carry goods through the temple.
And he was teaching and saying to them, "Is it not written: 'My house shall be called a house of prayer for all the nations'? But you have made it a den of bandits."
The chief priests and the scribes heard this and began looking for a way to destroy him, for they feared him—because the whole crowd was astonished at his teaching.
And whenever evening came, they would go out of the city.
As they passed by early in the morning, they saw the fig tree withered from the roots up.
And Peter, remembering, says to him, "Rabbi, look! The fig tree you cursed has withered."
Jesus answered and says to them, "Have faith in God.
Truly I tell you, whoever says to this mountain, 'Be lifted up and thrown into the sea,' and does not waver in his heart but believes that what he says is happening, it will be done for him.
For this reason I tell you, whatever you pray and ask for, believe that you have received it, and it will be yours.
And whenever you stand praying, forgive whatever you have against anyone, so that your Father in the heavens may also forgive you your trespasses."
They come again to Jerusalem. And as he was walking in the temple, the chief priests and the scribes and the elders come to him
and were saying to him, "By what authority are you doing these things? Or who gave you this authority to do them?"
Jesus said to them, "I will ask you one question. Answer me, and I will tell you by what authority I do these things.
The baptism of John—was it from heaven or from human beings? Answer me."
They were debating among themselves, saying, "What should we say? If we say, 'From heaven,' he will say, 'Then why did you not believe him?'
But if we say, 'From human beings'—" They feared the crowd, for everyone held that John was truly a prophet.
So they answered Jesus, "We do not know." And Jesus says to them, "Neither will I tell you by what authority I do these things."

chapters.notes:
**Historic present tense**: Mark frequently shifts to present tense for vividness ("he sends," "they bring," "says to him"). I preserved many of these to capture Mark's characteristic urgent, immediate narrative style, particularly in dialogue introductions.

**"The Lord" (v. 3)**: The Greek ὁ κύριος is ambiguous—it could mean "the owner" or "the Lord" (a title). The ambiguity appears intentional; on the surface it explains the transaction to the bystanders, but for Mark's readers it carries deeper significance.

**"Hosanna" (vv. 9-10)**: Retained as transliteration. This is the Hebrew/Aramaic הושיעה נא ("Save, please!") from Psalm 118:25. By the first century it had become a liturgical acclamation, so preserving the word captures what the original audience heard—a familiar festival cry with messianic overtones.

**"Den of bandits" (v. 17)**: The Greek λῃστῶν refers to violent robbers or bandits, not petty thieves. In Jeremiah 7:11 (which Jesus quotes), the "den" is where bandits retreat to feel safe after their crimes—the critique is not that the temple has become a place of cheating, but that it has become a refuge for those who commit injustice elsewhere while presuming on God's protection.

**"For all the nations" (v. 17)**: Mark alone among the Synoptics includes this phrase from Isaiah 56:7. This detail is significant for Mark's likely Gentile audience and highlights that Jesus's action concerns the Court of the Gentiles specifically.

**Verse 19 imperfect tense**: "They would go out" captures the iterative force of ἐξεπορεύοντο—this was their regular practice during this period, not a single event.

**"Believe that you have received it" (v. 24)**: The aorist ἐλάβετε ("you received") is striking—past tense. The grammar suggests believing in the reception as already accomplished, not merely hoping for future fulfillment.

**Verse 26 omitted**: Following the critical text (NA28/SBLGNT), which lacks this verse in the earliest manuscripts. It appears to be a later scribal addition harmonizing with Matthew 6:15.

verses.text: And he began to speak to them in parables: "A man planted a vineyard, and put a fence around it, and dug a pit for the winepress, and built a watchtower. Then he leased it to tenant farmers and went abroad.
At harvest time he sent a slave to the tenants to collect from them some of the fruit of the vineyard.
But they seized him, beat him, and sent him away empty-handed.
Again he sent another slave to them, and that one they struck on the head and treated shamefully.
And he sent another, and that one they killed—and many others, some they beat, some they killed.
"He still had one left: a beloved son. He sent him to them last, saying, 'They will respect my son.'
But those tenants said among themselves, 'This is the heir. Come, let us kill him, and the inheritance will be ours.'
And they seized him, killed him, and threw him out of the vineyard.
"What will the owner of the vineyard do? He will come and destroy those tenants and give the vineyard to others.
Have you not read this scripture: 'The stone that the builders rejected— this has become the cornerstone.
This came about from the Lord, and it is marvelous in our eyes'?"
And they were seeking to arrest him, but they feared the crowd, for they knew he had spoken the parable against them. So they left him and went away.
Then they send to him some of the Pharisees and some of the Herodians to trap him with a question.

And they came and said to him, "Teacher, we know that you are truthful and defer to no one, for you do not regard people's status, but teach the way of God in truth. Is it lawful to pay the poll tax to Caesar, or not? Should we pay, or should we not pay?"
But knowing their pretense, he said to them, "Why are you testing me? Bring me a denarius so I can look at it."
And they brought one. And he says to them, "Whose image is this, and whose inscription?" They said to him, "Caesar's."
And Jesus said to them, "Give back to Caesar what belongs to Caesar, and to God what belongs to God." And they were utterly amazed at him.
Then Sadducees come to him—the ones who say there is no resurrection—and they questioned him, saying,
"Teacher, Moses wrote for us that if a man's brother dies and leaves behind a wife but leaves no child, his brother should take the wife and raise up offspring for his brother.
There were seven brothers. The first took a wife, and dying he left no offspring.
And the second took her, and died leaving no offspring. And the third likewise.
And all seven left no offspring. Last of all, the woman also died.
In the resurrection, when they rise, whose wife will she be? For all seven had her as wife."
Jesus said to them, "Is this not why you go astray—because you know neither the scriptures nor the power of God?
For when they rise from the dead, they neither marry nor are given in marriage, but are like the angels in the heavens.

But concerning the dead, that they are raised—have you not read in the book of Moses, in the passage about the bush, how God said to him, 'I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob'?
He is not God of the dead, but of the living. You are greatly mistaken."
And one of the scribes approached, having heard them debating, and seeing that he answered them well, he asked him, "Which commandment is first of all?"
Jesus answered, "The first is: 'Hear, O Israel: the Lord our God, the Lord is one.
