And you shall love the Lord your God with all your heart, and with all your soul, and with all your mind, and with all your strength.'
The second is this: 'You shall love your neighbor as yourself.' There is no other commandment greater than these."
And the scribe said to him, "Well said, Teacher. You have spoken truly that he is one, and there is no other besides him.
And to love him with all the heart, and with all the understanding, and with all the strength, and to love one's neighbor as oneself—this is worth more than all burnt offerings and sacrifices."
And Jesus, seeing that he answered with insight, said to him, "You are not far from the kingdom of God." And no one any longer dared to question him.
And while teaching in the temple, Jesus responded by saying, "How is it that the scribes say the Messiah is David's son?
David himself, by the Holy Spirit, said: 'The Lord said to my lord, Sit at my right hand until I put your enemies under your feet.'
David himself calls him 'lord'—so how is he his son?" And the large crowd was listening to him with delight.
And in his teaching he said, "Beware of the scribes—the ones who desire to walk about in long robes, and want greetings in the marketplaces,
and the best seats in the synagogues, and the places of honor at banquets—
who devour the households of widows and for show offer lengthy prayers. These will receive a more severe judgment."
And sitting down across from the treasury, he was watching how the crowd was putting money into the treasury. Many wealthy people were putting in large amounts.
And a poor widow came and put in two small copper coins, which together make a penny.
And calling his disciples to him, he said to them, "Truly I tell you, this poor widow has put in more than all those contributing to the treasury.
For they all contributed out of their surplus, but she, out of her poverty, put in everything she had—her whole livelihood."

chapters.notes:
**"Beloved son" (v. 6)**: υἱὸν ἀγαπητόν uses the same language as Jesus's baptism and transfiguration ("This is my beloved son"). The original audience would recognize this parable as transparently allegorical—the vineyard owner is God, the son is Jesus.

**"Cornerstone" (v. 10)**: κεφαλὴν γωνίας literally means "head of the corner." This could refer to a cornerstone (foundation) or a capstone (completing the structure). Either maintains the paradox: what builders rejected becomes structurally essential.

**"Defer to no one... do not regard people's status" (v. 14)**: The Greek οὐ μέλει σοι περὶ οὐδενός and οὐ βλέπεις εἰς πρόσωπον ἀνθρώπων are Semitic idioms. The second phrase ("look at faces") means showing partiality based on social standing. The questioners' flattery is ironic—they're attempting manipulation by praising Jesus for being immune to manipulation.

**"Give back" (v. 17)**: ἀπόδοτε means "give back, return, repay"—not merely "give." The implication is that Caesar's things already belong to Caesar (hence have his image), while what bears God's image belongs to God. First-century hearers would catch the allusion: humans bear God's image (Genesis 1:26-27).

**"Pretense" (v. 15)**: ὑπόκρισιν here captures their staged sincerity—they're playing a role. "Hypocrisy" in modern English suggests believing one thing and doing another, but here the sense is theatrical: a performance designed to entrap.

**"In the passage about the bush" (v. 26)**: ἐπὶ τοῦ βάτου is a first-century way of citing scripture by subject matter (before chapter-and-verse divisions existed). It refers to the burning bush narrative in Exodus 3.

**"With insight" (v. 34)**: νουνεχῶς means "sensibly, with understanding, thoughtfully"—the scribe grasped not just the letter but the spirit of Jesus's answer.

**"Her whole livelihood" (v. 44)**: ὅλον τὸν βίον αὐτῆς—βίος here means not "life" abstractly but "means of living, livelihood." She gave everything she had to live on.

verses.text: And as he was going out from the temple, one of his disciples says to him, "Teacher, look! What remarkable stones! What remarkable buildings!"
And Jesus said to him, "Do you see these great buildings? Not one stone will be left here upon another that will not be torn down."
And as he sat on the Mount of Olives facing the temple, Peter and James and John and Andrew asked him privately,
"Tell us, when will these things happen? And what will be the sign when all these things are about to be completed?"
And Jesus began to say to them, "Watch out that no one leads you astray.
Many will come in my name saying, 'I am,' and they will lead many astray.
And when you hear of wars and reports of wars, do not be alarmed. These things must happen, but the end is not yet.
For nation will rise against nation and kingdom against kingdom. There will be earthquakes in various places. There will be famines. These things are the beginning of the birth pains.
"But watch out for yourselves. They will hand you over to councils, and you will be beaten in synagogues, and you will stand before governors and kings because of me, as a witness to them.
And first the good news must be proclaimed to all the nations.

And when they arrest you and hand you over, do not worry beforehand about what you will say. Instead, whatever is given to you in that hour, speak that—for it is not you who are speaking but the Holy Spirit.
And brother will hand over brother to death, and a father his child. And children will rise up against parents and put them to death.
And you will be hated by all because of my name. But the one who endures to the end—this one will be saved.
"But when you see the abomination of desolation standing where it should not be—let the reader understand—then those in Judea must flee to the mountains.
The one on the rooftop must not come down or go inside to take anything from his house.
And the one in the field must not turn back to get his cloak.
But how terrible it will be for those who are pregnant and for those who are nursing in those days!
Pray that it may not happen in winter.
For those days will be a time of affliction such as has not occurred from the beginning of the creation that God created until now, and never will again.
And if the Lord had not cut short those days, no flesh would be saved. But for the sake of the chosen ones whom he chose, he cut short the days.
"And then if anyone says to you, 'Look, here is the Messiah!' or 'Look, there!' do not believe it.
For false messiahs and false prophets will arise and will produce signs and wonders in order to lead astray, if possible, the chosen ones.
But you—be on guard. I have told you everything beforehand.
"But in those days, after that affliction, the sun will be darkened, and the moon will not give its light,
and the stars will be falling from heaven, and the powers in the heavens will be shaken.
And then they will see the Son of Man coming in clouds with great power and glory.
And then he will send the angels and gather his chosen ones from the four winds, from the farthest reach of earth to the farthest reach of heaven.
"Now learn the lesson from the fig tree: when its branch has already become tender and puts forth its leaves, you know that summer is near.
So also you, when you see these things happening, know that he is near, at the very doors.
Truly I say to you that this generation will certainly not pass away until all these things have happened.
Heaven and earth will pass away, but my words will certainly not pass away.
"But concerning that day or the hour, no one knows—not the angels in heaven, not even the Son—except the Father.
Be on guard, stay awake, for you do not know when the appointed time is.
It is like a man going on a journey who left his house and gave his servants authority, to each one his own task, and commanded the doorkeeper to keep watch.
Keep watch, then, for you do not know when the master of the house is coming—whether late in the evening, or at midnight, or at cockcrow, or at dawn—
lest he come suddenly and find you sleeping.
And what I say to you, I say to all: Keep watch."

chapters.notes:
**"I am" (v. 6)**: The Greek Ἐγώ εἰμι is left ambiguous in the source—it could mean "I am [the Messiah]" or could echo the divine name (Exodus 3:14). Rather than inserting "he" (as many translations do), I preserve the ambiguity that Mark's original readers would have encountered.

**"Birth pains" (v. 8)**: The Greek ὠδίνων carries significant eschatological weight. In Jewish apocalyptic tradition, the "birth pangs of the Messiah" referred to the period of intense suffering preceding the messianic age. This metaphor suggests not random suffering but labor that produces something—the new age.

**"Abomination of desolation standing where it should not be" (v. 14)**: The participle ἑστηκότα is masculine, though βδέλυγμα ("abomination") is neuter. This grammatical anomaly may personalize the abomination, pointing to a figure rather than merely an object. The phrase itself alludes to Daniel (9:27, 11:31, 12:11).

**"Let the reader understand" (v. 14)**: This editorial aside (ὁ ἀναγινώσκων νοείτω) breaks the narrative frame and speaks directly to whoever is reading Mark's Gospel aloud to a congregation—a striking moment of authorial intrusion.

**"All flesh" (v. 20)**: The Semitic idiom πᾶσα σάρξ ("all flesh") means "any living person" or "anyone at all." I've translated it "no flesh would be saved" to preserve the idiomatic feel while making the meaning clear.

**"The Son" (v. 32)**: The explicit statement that even the Son does not know the day or hour is textually secure in Mark and represents a striking claim about the limits of Jesus's earthly knowledge.

**"Late evening... midnight... cockcrow... dawn" (v. 35)**: These represent the four Roman watches of the night (roughly 6-9pm, 9pm-midnight, midnight-3am, 3-6am). The terminology reflects Mark's Roman audience.

**"Keep watch" (v. 33, 34, 35, 37)**: The Greek γρηγορέω (and related ἀγρυπνέω in v. 33) carries both the literal sense of staying physically awake and the metaphorical sense of spiritual vigilance. The repetition of this command four times at the discourse's end creates a drumbeat of urgency.

verses.text: Now the Passover and the Festival of Unleavened Bread was two days away. And the chief priests and the scribes were seeking how to seize him by stealth and kill him.
For they were saying, "Not during the festival, or there will be an uproar among the people."
While he was in Bethany in the house of Simon the leper, reclining at table, a woman came with an alabaster jar of very costly perfume of pure nard. She broke the jar and poured it over his head.
But some were indignant among themselves: "Why has this waste of the perfume happened?
This perfume could have been sold for more than three hundred denarii and given to the poor!" And they were rebuking her harshly.
But Jesus said, "Leave her alone. Why are you troubling her? She has done a beautiful deed for me.
For the poor you always have with you, and whenever you wish you can do good for them. But you do not always have me.
What she could, she did—she anointed my body beforehand for burial.
Truly I tell you, wherever the good news is proclaimed in the whole world, what she has done will also be spoken of as a memorial to her."
And Judas Iscariot, one of the twelve, went away to the chief priests in order to hand him over to them.
When they heard this, they were delighted and promised to give him money. And he began seeking how to hand him over at an opportune time.
On the first day of Unleavened Bread, when they were sacrificing the Passover lamb, his disciples say to him, "Where do you want us to go and prepare so that you may eat the Passover?"
And he sends two of his disciples and says to them, "Go into the city, and a man carrying a water jar will meet you. Follow him.
And wherever he enters, say to the master of the house, 'The Teacher says: Where is my guest room where I may eat the Passover with my disciples?'
And he will show you a large upper room, furnished and ready. Prepare for us there."
The disciples went out and came into the city and found it just as he had told them, and they prepared the Passover.
When evening came, he arrives with the twelve.
While they were reclining and eating, Jesus said, "Truly I tell you, one of you will hand me over—one who is eating with me."
They began to be distressed and to say to him one by one, "Surely not I?"
He said to them, "One of the twelve—the one dipping with me into the dish.
For the Son of Man goes as it has been written concerning him, but woe to that man through whom the Son of Man is handed over! It would be better for that man if he had not been born."
While they were eating, he took bread, spoke a blessing, broke it, and gave it to them and said, "Take; this is my body."
And taking a cup, he gave thanks and gave it to them, and they all drank from it.
And he said to them, "This is my blood of the covenant, which is poured out for many.
Truly I tell you, I will certainly not drink again of the fruit of the vine until that day when I drink it new in the kingdom of God."
And after singing a hymn, they went out to the Mount of Olives.
And Jesus says to them, "You will all fall away, for it is written: 'I will strike the shepherd, and the sheep will be scattered.'
But after I am raised, I will go before you to Galilee."
But Peter said to him, "Even if all fall away, I will not."
And Jesus says to him, "Truly I tell you, today—this very night—before the rooster crows twice, you will deny me three times."
But he kept saying vehemently, "Even if I must die with you, I will never deny you!" And they all were saying the same.
They come to a place called Gethsemane, and he says to his disciples, "Sit here while I pray."
And he takes Peter and James and John with him, and he began to be deeply alarmed and troubled.
And he says to them, "My soul is overwhelmed with grief to the point of death. Remain here and keep watch."
And going forward a little, he fell upon the ground and was praying that if it were possible, the hour might pass from him.
And he was saying, "Abba—Father—all things are possible for you. Take this cup from me. Yet not what I will, but what you will."
And he comes and finds them sleeping, and says to Peter, "Simon, are you sleeping? Were you not strong enough to keep watch one hour?
Keep watch and pray so that you may not enter into testing. The spirit is willing, but the flesh is weak."
And again he went away and prayed, saying the same words.
And coming back again, he found them sleeping, for their eyes were weighed down. And they did not know what to answer him.
He comes a third time and says to them, "Are you still sleeping and resting? It is finished. The hour has come. Look—the Son of Man is being handed over into the hands of sinners.
Get up, let us go. Look—the one handing me over has drawn near."
And immediately, while he was still speaking, Judas arrives—one of the twelve—and with him a crowd with swords and clubs, from the chief priests and the scribes and the elders.
Now the one handing him over had given them a signal, saying, "The one I kiss is the man. Seize him and lead him away under guard."
And arriving, he immediately went up to him and says, "Rabbi!"—and kissed him fervently.
And they laid hands on him and seized him.
But one of those standing by drew his sword and struck the servant of the high priest and cut off his ear.
And Jesus responded and said to them, "Have you come out as against a revolutionary, with swords and clubs to arrest me?
Day after day I was with you in the temple teaching, and you did not seize me. But let the scriptures be fulfilled."
And leaving him, they all fled.
And a certain young man was following him, wearing only a linen cloth over his naked body. They seized him,
but leaving the linen cloth behind, he fled naked.
They led Jesus away to the high priest, and all the chief priests and the elders and the scribes assembled.
And Peter followed him at a distance, right into the courtyard of the high priest. And he was sitting with the guards and warming himself by the fire.
Now the chief priests and the whole council were seeking testimony against Jesus to put him to death, but they could not find any.
For many were testifying falsely against him, but their testimonies did not agree.
And some stood up and testified falsely against him, saying,
"We heard him say, 'I will destroy this temple made with hands, and in three days I will build another not made with hands.'"
Yet even so their testimony did not agree.
And the high priest stood up in the midst and questioned Jesus, saying, "Do you answer nothing? What is this these men testify against you?"
But he was silent and answered nothing. Again the high priest questioned him and says to him, "Are you the Messiah, the Son of the Blessed One?"
And Jesus said, "I am. And you will see the Son of Man seated at the right hand of
And immediately at dawn, the chief priests, having held a council with the elders and scribes and the whole Sanhedrin, bound Jesus and led him away and handed him over to Pilate.
Pilate questioned him: "Are you the King of the Jews?" He answered him, "You say so."
The chief priests were accusing him of many things.
Pilate questioned him again, saying, "Have you no answer? Look how many charges they are bringing against you."
But Jesus made no further reply at all, so that Pilate was astonished.
Now at each festival he used to release to them one prisoner, whomever they requested.
There was a man called Barabbas, imprisoned with the insurrectionists who had committed murder during the uprising.
The crowd came up and began to ask Pilate to do as he customarily did for them.
Pilate answered them, saying, "Do you want me to release to you the King of the Jews?"
For he recognized that it was out of envy that the chief priests had handed him over.
But the chief priests stirred up the crowd to have him release Barabbas to them instead.
Pilate again responded and said to them, "Then what do you want me to do with the one you call the King of the Jews?"
They shouted back, "Crucify him!"
Pilate said to them, "Why? What crime has he committed?" But they shouted all the more, "Crucify him!"
So Pilate, wanting to satisfy the crowd, released Barabbas to them, and after having Jesus flogged, handed him over to be crucified.
The soldiers led him away into the courtyard—that is, the governor's residence—and they called together the whole cohort.
They dressed him in purple and placed on him a crown they had woven from thorns.
And they began to salute him: "Hail, King of the Jews!"
They kept striking his head with a reed and spitting on him, and bending their knees, they kept doing obeisance to him.
When they had finished mocking him, they stripped off the purple and put his own clothes back on him. Then they led him out to crucify him.
They pressed into service a passerby, Simon from Cyrene, coming in from the countryside—the father of Alexander and Rufus—to carry his cross.
They brought him to the place called Golgotha, which is translated "Place of a Skull."
They offered him wine mixed with myrrh, but he did not take it.
And they crucified him and divided up his garments, casting lots for them to decide who would take what.
It was the third hour when they crucified him.
The inscription of the charge against him read: THE KING OF THE JEWS.
With him they crucified two bandits, one on his right and one on his left.
Those passing by were hurling insults at him, shaking their heads and saying, "Ha! You who would destroy the temple and rebuild it in three days—
save yourself by coming down from the cross!"
Likewise the chief priests, mocking him among themselves together with the scribes, said, "He saved others—himself he cannot save!
Let the Messiah, the King of Israel, come down now from the cross so that we may see and believe!" Even those who were crucified with him were reviling him.
When the sixth hour came, darkness fell over the whole land until the ninth hour.
At the ninth hour Jesus cried out with a loud voice, "Eloi, Eloi, lema sabachthani?"—which is translated, "My God, my God, why have you abandoned me?"
Some of those standing nearby, when they heard it, said, "Look, he is calling for Elijah."
Someone ran and filled a sponge with sour wine, put it on a reed, and gave it to him to drink, saying, "Wait—let us see if Elijah comes to take him down."
But Jesus, letting out a loud cry, breathed his last.
And the curtain of the temple was torn in two, from top to bottom.
When the centurion standing opposite him saw that he died in this way, he said, "Truly this man was God's son."
There were also women watching from a distance, among them Mary Magdalene, and Mary the mother of James the younger and of Joses, and Salome—
who, when he was in Galilee, used to follow him and serve him—and many other women who had come up with him to Jerusalem.
When evening had already come, since it was Preparation Day—that is, the day before the Sabbath—
Joseph of Arimathea, a prominent council member who was himself awaiting the kingdom of God, gathered his courage and went to Pilate and requested the body of Jesus.
Pilate was surprised that he was already dead, and summoning the centurion, he asked him whether he had been dead for long.
When he learned this from the centurion, he granted the corpse to Joseph.
Joseph purchased a linen cloth, took him down, wrapped him in the linen, and laid him in a tomb that had been cut from rock. Then he rolled a stone against the entrance of the tomb.
Mary Magdalene and Mary the mother of Joses were watching where he was laid.

chapters.notes:
**"You say so" (v. 2)**: The Greek Σὺ λέγεις is deliberately ambiguous—neither a clear affirmation nor denial. Jesus neither claims nor denies the title, leaving Pilate to draw his own conclusions. This evasiveness is characteristic of Jesus's responses throughout the trial.

**"Handed over" (vv. 1, 10, 15)**: The verb παραδίδωμι recurs throughout Mark's passion narrative—used of Judas betraying Jesus, the Sanhedrin delivering him to Pilate, and Pilate delivering him for crucifixion. This repetition creates a chain of "handing over" that the translation preserves.

**"Insurrectionists" (v. 7)**: στασιαστῶν refers to those involved in political rebellion against Rome. Barabbas was not merely a criminal but a revolutionary—making the crowd's choice between him and Jesus politically charged.

**"Salute" (v. 18)**: ἀσπάζεσθαι combined with "Hail" (Χαῖρε) parodies the imperial greeting "Ave Caesar." The mockery is a grotesque parody of Roman imperial ceremony.

**"Doing obeisance" (v. 19)**: προσεκύνουν can mean "worship" but also the physical act of prostration before royalty. The soldiers are performing mock homage, not religious worship—though Mark's readers would recognize the irony.

**"God's son" (v. 39)**: The Greek υἱὸς θεοῦ lacks the definite article. The centurion, a pagan, might mean "a son of a god" in Greco-Roman terms, while Mark's readers would understand the fuller Christian meaning. "God's son" preserves this productive ambiguity better than "the Son of God" or "a son of God."

**Verse 28**: This verse, which reads "And the scripture was fulfilled that says, 'He was counted among the lawless,'" is absent from the earliest manuscripts and thus omitted following the critical text.

**"Hurling insults" (v. 29)**: ἐβλασφήμουν literally means "blaspheming," but the word's range in Greek includes reviling or speaking abusively. The irony is that the mockers, not Jesus, are the true blasphemers.

**"Abandoned" (v. 34)**: While "forsaken" is traditional, ἐγκατέλιπες (from Psalm 22:1) carries the sense of being left behind, abandoned. Jesus quotes the opening of a psalm that moves from desperation to vindication—a fact first-century Jewish listeners would recognize.

**"Breathed his last" (v. 37)**: ἐξέπνευσεν literally means "breathed out" or "expired." The same verb appears in v. 39, linking Jesus's death to the centurion's confession.

verses.text: When the Sabbath had passed, Mary of Magdala, Mary the mother of James, and Salome bought aromatic spices so that they could go and anoint him.
Very early on the first day of the week, they come to the tomb just as the sun had risen.
They were saying to one another, "Who will roll away the stone from the entrance of the tomb for us?"
But when they looked up, they see that the stone had been rolled away—for it was extremely large.
Entering the tomb, they saw a young man sitting on the right side, clothed in a white robe, and they were utterly overcome with alarm.
But he says to them, "Do not be alarmed. You are looking for Jesus the Nazarene, the one who was crucified. He has been raised—he is not here. Look, there is the place where they laid him.
But go, tell his disciples and Peter: 'He is going ahead of you into Galilee. There you will see him, just as he told you.'"
And going out, they fled from the tomb, for trembling and bewilderment had seized them. And they said nothing to anyone—for they were afraid.

chapters.notes:
**Verses 9-20 and the "Shorter Ending" omitted**: The double-bracketed material in the source text represents later additions not found in the earliest and most reliable manuscripts (including Codex Sinaiticus and Codex Vaticanus). Mark's Gospel, as originally preserved, ends at verse 8 with the startling phrase "for they were afraid." The abruptness—ending a Greek sentence with γάρ ("for") is almost unparalleled—has generated centuries of scholarly debate about whether this was Mark's intended ending or whether the original conclusion was lost.

**Historical presents preserved (vv. 2, 4, 6)**: Mark's Gospel frequently uses present-tense verbs in past-time narration ("they come," "they see," "he says") to create vivid immediacy. I retained these rather than smoothing them into past tense.

**"He has been raised" (v. 6)**: The Greek ἠγέρθη is an aorist passive—"was raised" with an implied divine agent. This is the so-called "divine passive," indicating God as the one who raised Jesus without naming God directly.

**"Utterly overcome with alarm" (v. 5)**: The verb ἐξεθαμβήθησαν (found only in Mark in the NT) is intensified by its prefix and conveys overwhelming, disorienting alarm—stronger than mere surprise.

**"Trembling and bewilderment" (v. 8)**: The Greek τρόμος καὶ ἔκστασις pairs physical trembling with ἔκστασις—literally "standing outside oneself," a state of being displaced from normal consciousness by overwhelming experience. "Bewilderment" captures this better than "amazement," which sounds too positive.

**"And Peter" (v. 7)**: The singling out of Peter alongside "his disciples" is striking—likely acknowledging Peter's denial while assuring his restoration.
